issues.title: iot commands require output filename
issues.body:
The **iot-data** commands such as **get-thing-shadow** and **update-thing-shadow** require a filename parameter. Output from the commands is directed to that file rather than to stdout.  The filename is required and even the common *nix designation for stdout, "-", does not work. 

This behavior is inconsistent with most other CLI commands and works against the normal composition of *nix commands.  The output is JSON so a user should reasonably expect the output to go to stdout. As it stands, there is no way to pipe the output and a user is forced to contend with cleaning up temporary files.

These commands should be consistent with the *nix conventions (and the bulk of other AWS CLI commands) by writing semantic output to stdout and letting the caller decide whether to redirect to a file.

This should be fixed before the use of intermediate files for what should be simple piping becomes widespread.

issues.title: Non zero RC for S3 sync even if file is excluded
issues.body:
A file that would is `--exclude`'d should not trigger a non zero RC if we can't read the file.  For example:

```
/tmp $ mkdir demo
/tmp $ mkfifo demo/bad
/tmp $ touch demo/good
/tmp $ aws s3 sync demo/ s3://bucket/demo/ --exclude '*' --dryrun
warning: Skipping file /private/tmp/demo/bad. File is character special device, block special device, FIFO, or socket.
Completed 0 part(s) with ... file(s) remaining
/tmp $ echo $?
2
```

Given that `/tmp/demo/bad` was never going to be transferred in the first place (because it's been excluded via `--exclude '*'`, it seems odd that this will trigger a non zero RC.  I'd expect the RC to be 0 here.

issues.title: Add ability for S3 commands to increase retry count
issues.body:
We've seen several issues opened now where, due to a number of variables, the max number of attempts, which is currently 5, is too low.  This can be due to a less reliable WAN link, the available resources on the machine running the commands not being sufficient, the parallelism for S3 transfers being too high, etc.

To help with this issue, we should provide some sort of mechanism that allows a user to bump up the retry count.  The main use case would be when transferring either a large amount of files or large files.  In these scenarios you're more willing to retry as many times as needed to get the request to succeed.

See:

https://github.com/aws/aws-cli/issues/1065

issues.title: Add support for PAGER/AWS_PAGER
issues.body: We've had feature requests to support a PAGER/AWS_PAGER environment variable.  It would work similar to other CLIs that support a pager env var in that any output would be sent to the pager if the var is set (provided it would take up more than one page).

Confirmed this is still an issue in the develop branch of awscli/botocore.

There's two problems here, one is that the cli is missing an `abspath` (otherwise we'll assume the current drive is where we should be looking).  The other is that the data path in botocore uses `:` as the separator for environment variables, which is standard in the posix world, but on windows env vars use `;` to separate variables because a path can have a `:` character in it, and splitting on `:` would not give us what we want:

```
>>> import os
>>> os.environ['PATH']
'C:\\Windows\\system32;C:\\Windows;C:\\Windows\\System32\\Wbem;C:\\Windows\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\;C:\\Program Files\\Amazon\\cfn-bootstrap\\'
>>> os.environ['PATH'].split(':')
['C', '\\Windows\\system32;C', '\\Windows;C', '\\Windows\\System32\\Wbem;C', '\\Windows\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\;C', '\\Program Files\\Amazon\\cfn-bootstrap\\']
```

Working on a fix for this now.  I'll add the appropriate `abspath` call in the cli and I'll add a windows specific separator char for these path env vars.

issues.title: Corrupted downloads when a file on S3 changes mid-download
issues.body:
We're observing behavior where aws-cli downloads a corrupt file from S3 if the file is replaced mid-download. We're thinking this happens because of multipart downloads -- each part fetched is consistent with some version of the file, but some of the parts are coming from different versions of the file.

In the end, we end up with aws-cli exiting zero but a corrupted file that produces errors further along in our processing.

### Reproduction

This reproduces the issue almost 100% of the time:

1. Make a virtualenv and install the latest aws-cli:
    ```bash
    virtualenv -ppython2.7 venv && venv/bin/pip install awscli
    ```
1. Make eight files files `f0` through `f7` which each consist of 1GB of a single byte repeated:
    ```bash
    for i in {0..7}; do
        dd if=/dev/zero bs=1M count=1000 | tr '\000' "\00${i}" > "f${i}"
    done
    ```
2. Upload some of these files fully, with other uploads still in-progress, to the same key, then start a download of that key using aws-cli. Here's one example script:
    ```bash
    #!/usr/bin/time bash
    set -euo pipefail
    n="$RANDOM"
    key="s3://my-bucket/test-${n}"
    results="result-${n}"

    # stagger the uploads a bit, start them all in the background
    for f in f*; do
        venv/bin/aws s3 cp "$f" "$key" &
        sleep 5
    done

    # wait for the first three to finish
    wait %1
    wait %2
    wait %3

    venv/bin/aws s3 cp "$key" "$results"
    my_hash=$(openssl sha1 "$results" | cut -d' ' -f2)
    echo "my hash is: $my_hash"
    ```
3. Compare the hash of the uploaded file with the `f` files, and it's usually different:
    ```bash
    $ openssl sha1 result-3854 f*
    SHA1(result-3854)= 99db13b557cb00b7b15410bad1c360e89b530f58
    SHA1(f0)= cb19f836c2830ff88ff45694565da65be73b7a69
    SHA1(f1)= eee4fdda7e8ac4955b9d4b97fb823c07ba0f73b4
    SHA1(f2)= c4f79272572f3fd74800c2d7b83c936646475c2e
    SHA1(f3)= bc143c1ff8156c7ab8d41f4a700c1f2d16fbadb3
    SHA1(f4)= f035d33802e80e293f9cdcc307474809a6c45ad1
    SHA1(f5)= d406dcd45e1a85050ce0eaa34f708de4cf25b142
    SHA1(f6)= 13f9c9358cd0824395f2890aacdced2e93b33f27
    SHA1(f7)= 77bbea0dad5295f4e67c371825f0b1a857cc4b5b
    ```

    Looking at the hexdump, the downloaded file is a mix of f2, f3, f5, f6, and f7:
    ```
    $ hd result-3854
    00000000  02 02 02 02 02 02 02 02  02 02 02 02 02 02 02 02  |................|
    *
    0e800000  03 03 03 03 03 03 03 03  03 03 03 03 03 03 03 03  |................|
    *
    16800000  05 05 05 05 05 05 05 05  05 05 05 05 05 05 05 05  |................|
    *
    1a800000  06 06 06 06 06 06 06 06  06 06 06 06 06 06 06 06  |................|
    *
    20800000  07 07 07 07 07 07 07 07  07 07 07 07 07 07 07 07  |................|
    *
    3e800000
    ```

I did these steps on Debian stretch.

### Expected behavior

It'd be great if `aws-cli` could either download the file consistently, or at least detect that it has downloaded a corrupted file and exit nonzero to avoid propagating errors.

issues.title: aws cloudformation package command will not output JSON despite documentation
issues.body:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/using-cfn-cli-package.html

Indicates that I should be able to generate a JSON-formatted cloudformation template. I have a template that is already in JSON as follows:

```json
{
  "AWSTemplateFormatVersion" : "2010-09-09",
  "Transform" : "AWS::Serverless-2016-10-31",

  "Resources": {

    "ApiLambdaFunc": {
      "Type" : "AWS::Lambda::Function",
      "Properties" : {
        "Code": "./",
        "Description": "foo bar",
        "FunctionName": "foo",
        "Handler": "index.handler",
        "MemorySize": "128",
        "Runtime": "nodejs4.3",
        "Timeout": "2"
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Then I run:
```sh
aws cloudformation package --s3-bucket <<REDACTED>> --template cloudformation/template.json --output-template-file foo.json
```

But then foo.json is yaml:
```yml
AWSTemplateFormatVersion: '2010-09-09'
Resources:
  ApiLambdaFunc:
    Properties:
      Code:
        S3Bucket: <<REDACTED>
        S3Key: <<REDACTED>>
      Description: foo bar
      FunctionName: foo
      Handler: index.handler
      MemorySize: '128'
      Runtime: nodejs4.3
      Timeout: '2'
    Type: AWS::Lambda::Function
Transform: AWS::Serverless-2016-10-31
```
I've also tried command of the form (as shown on docs page):
```sh
 aws cloudformation package --s3-bucket <<REDACTED>> --template cloudformation/template.json --output json
```
aws cli version: aws-cli/1.11.24 Python/2.7.12 Linux/4.4.0-51-generic botocore/1.4.81


I installed using instructions from:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/installing.html#install-bundle-other-os

issues.title: Local caching for read-only ops
issues.body:
I couldn't find any issues/feature-requests describing this.  The aws cli tools would be much easier to use in an iterative style if read-only data retrieved from the API could be cached locally for a time.  This would have transitive benefits of limiting the number of calls made and lowering network traffic for AWS and the end-user.  I think this would be most useful as a CLI flag that could be used on an adhoc basis, as in this example:

```
aws cloudformation describe-stacks --cache 60s
```

* first execution of above would make remote call, cache data locally, then spit out results
* subsequent executions of above within 60 seconds would return the locally cached data with no API call
* an execution after 60 seconds would refresh the stale local data.

Purging/cleanup of stale data so that it doesn't clutter the local file system would be an issue.  Some ideas:


* Document where the cache is located and let people know they may want to clean it periodically using standard tools (`rm`, etc...)
* Have it located within `tmp` so that it gets cleaned up periodically by the OS
* Have a cleanup command that can be run periodically and leave it up to the user as to when/if its run
* Purge any stale data every time an `aws` command is invoked.

issues.title: PyYAML requires python-dev dependency
issues.body:
Hi,

It seems the latest release of `awscli` requires [PyYAML as its dependency](https://github.com/aws/aws-cli/blame/develop/requirements.txt#L14). I noticed that this dependency breaks my CI test in Ubuntu 14.04.

It returned the following error:

```
  Running setup.py install for PyYAML
    checking if libyaml is compilable
    x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O2 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -I/usr/include/python2.7 -c build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/check_libyaml.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/check_libyaml.o
    checking if libyaml is linkable
    x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc -pthread build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/check_libyaml.o -lyaml -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/check_libyaml
    building '_yaml' extension
    x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O2 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -I/usr/include/python2.7 -c ext/_yaml.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/ext/_yaml.o
    ext/_yaml.c:4:20: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
     #include "Python.h"
                        ^
    compilation terminated.
    error: command 'x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

I'm wondering, is it possible to use `awscli` via `pip install awscli` without adding extra `python-dev` dependency? Or if it's required to use extra dependency, I think it's a good idea to put it in the documentation.

Thank you!

issues.title: aws-cli fails to acquire session token before issuing sts:AssumeRole call
issues.body:
AWS CLI fails while attempting to issue API calls with MFA authentication. It appears to be issuing a `sts:AssumeRole` API call without generating or passing an appropriate session token as part of the call.

As a result, the use of MFA authentication with a role fails.

Here's the basic config:

```
[user]
aws_access_key_id=ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRST
aws_secret_access_key=ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ1234567890ABCD

[role]
role_arn=arn:aws:iam::123456789101:/role/UserRole
source_profile=user
mfa_serial=arn:aws:iam::123456789101:mfa/user
```

I invoke the role like this:

```
aws --profile=role s3 ls --debug
```

Here's the debug output as a GIST:

https://gist.github.com/cbarbour/f3785cb5111009e27d6d1517b1bc5171

I've confirmed that the MFA token works fine with the web interface. ~~I've also confirmed that I can generate a MFA authenticated session on the command line manually, allowing me to acquire the role.~~

I've enabled cloudtrace, and confirmed that the failed authentication attempts do not contain the appropriate credentials.

Normally, I'd expect to see a user identity like this:

```
            "userIdentity": {
                "accessKeyId": "...",
                "accountId": "...",
                "arn": "arn:aws:iam::...:user/...",
                "invokedBy": "signin.amazonaws.com",
                "principalId": "...",
                "sessionContext": {
                    "attributes": {
                        "creationDate": "2016-11-09T20:36:48Z",
                        "mfaAuthenticated": "true"
                    }
                },
                "type": "IAMUser",
                "userName": "..."
            }
```

However, when I attempt to authenticate using a role, the resulting cloudtrail entry looks like this:

```

        {
            "awsRegion": "us-east-1",
            "errorCode": "AccessDenied",
            "errorMessage": "Not authorized to perform sts:AssumeRole",
            "eventID": "...",
            "eventName": "AssumeRole",
            "eventSource": "sts.amazonaws.com",
            "eventTime": "2016-11-09T21:48:21Z",
            "eventType": "AwsApiCall",
            "eventVersion": "1.05",
            "recipientAccountId": "...",
            "requestID": "...",
            "requestParameters": null,
            "responseElements": null,
            "sourceIPAddress": "...",
            "userAgent": "aws-cli/1.11.13 Python/3.5.2 Darwin/15.5.0 botocore/1.4.70",
            "userIdentity": {
                "accessKeyId": "...",
                "accountId": "...",
                "arn": "arn:aws:iam::...:user/...",
                "principalId": "...",
                "type": "IAMUser",
                "userName": "..."
            }
        }
```

I suspect this is a Boto bug rather than an aws-cli bug, however I felt it best to file here since I haven't attempted to reproduce the problem using botocore.

issues.title: Cloudformation external parameter file do not support YAML file
issues.body:
I used aws-cli to update my stacks, and want to use an external yaml file (dev.yaml) as parameters file like below:
```sh
aws cloudformation update-stack --stack-name test --template-body file://./api-test.yaml --parameters file://./dev.yaml
```
In `dev.yaml`, it only has:
```yaml

---
- ParameterKey: APICacheClusterSize
  ParameterValue: '1.6'
```
However, I got this Error message when I run the update command above:
```
Error parsing parameter '--parameters': Expected: '=', received: '-' for input:

---
- ParameterKey: APICacheClusterSize
^
  ParameterValue: '1.6'
```

If I use JSON file with same context as below, and use it instead of `dev.yaml`, it works fine:
```json
[
  {
    "ParameterKey": "APICacheClusterSize",
    "ParameterValue": "1.6"
  }
]
```

So, can the external parameters file for aws cloudformation be YAML file? or will...?

issues.title: Code deploy changing app name?
issues.body:
When I issue a code deploy command like so

    aws --region us-west-2 deploy register-application-revision --application-name my-notification-svc --s3-location bucket=my-bkt,bundleType=zip,key=my-notification-svc.zip

I'm getting

    An error occurred (ApplicationDoesNotExistException) when calling the RegisterApplicationRevision operation: No application found for name: my-Trigger-svc

A `my-notification-svc` app does exist, but the command appears to have swapped out `notification` in the name for `Trigger` somehow. What could possibly be causing this?

issues.title: Add progress bar UI for s3 copying
issues.body:
If you're in higher latency parts of the world where connectivity isn't great (e.g. Australia, India, Israel), not having the progress output appear until after the first 5 MB is insufficient. I regularly upload 100 MB files from Sydney to an S3 bucket in the East US and it's beyond frustrating to have no output from the CLI.

**Expected behaviors:**
1. Upload a file from the CLI with aws s3 cp s3://bucket/file.ext 
2. View file progress/output as soon as the command executes

**Current behaviour:**
1. Upload a file from the CLI with aws s3 s3://bucket/file.ext 
2. Sit at an empty terminal for extended periods of time

The current behaviour leads to a poor interaction and negatively impacts the experience of the aws s3 cp command. 

This is taken from the comments of issue #312 , as it seems there is still a large demand for this feature.

issues.title: Improve "region" validation
issues.body:
HI, 

I got stuck in a pretty bad debugging loop based on a very misleading error message. 

I had set my region as us-east-1d, not us-east-1. Somehow this resulted in an SSL Protocol Unknown exception (requests.exceptions.args SSL UNKNOWN_PROTOCOL). This led me down a rabbit hole of installing certifi, wondering if the python3 vs python2 version was an issue, etc etc. 

I see there is even a stub which is supposed to do some region validation, but it only checks that the region exists:

https://github.com/aws/aws-cli/blob/develop/awscli/customizations/codedeploy/utils.py#L48

Is there a way to make this more robust? I don't know what patterns are valid regions, or if there is a way to check at runtime, but there must be a better way to handle an error like mine. 

I'm game to try to help improve this so others don't get stuck like I do, but I am not certain how.

tnx

issues.title: "aws s3 ls" should have a summary-only option
issues.body:
When dealing with large buckets with many files in them, it would be good to have a "summary-only" option, so that the individual files are not listed. Instead, the CLI would simply print the summary information, which includes the number of objects and the total size of those objects.

I could use a shell script to filter the output, but it still takes a while to run, and I imagine that a significant part of that time could be reduced by disabling the full output.

Example command to filter the output:

```
aws s3 ls "mybucket" --summarize --recursive | grep -P "(Total Objects|Total Size)"
```

My CLI version: aws-cli/1.10.1

issues.title: Invalid S3 v4 signed request when using non-AWS endpoint
issues.body:
As best i can tell, when using an AWS endpoint, `aws s3` commands default to v2 request signing. But when using a non-AWS endpoint (Eucalyptus in my case), `aws s3` attempts to use v4 request signing, except that the request is missing an `x-amz-content-sha256` header which makes it invalid. 

Here's an example command that does this:

```
aws --endpoint-url http://s3.d-23.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/ s3 cp ExampleObject.txt s3://examples-test/
```

And here's the corresponding server-side ngrep packet capture for that command:

```
  PUT /examples-test/ExampleObject.txt HTTP/1.1..Host: s3.d-23.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773..Accept-Encoding: identity..Content-Length: 857..Content-MD5: WZurPtLGl/HSaEJydWH9lA==..Expect: 100-continue..X-Amz-Date: 20161021T
  001844Z..User-Agent: aws-cli/1.11.6 Python/2.7.10 Darwin/14.5.0 botocore/1.4.63..Content-Type: text/plain..Authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=REDACTED, SignedHeaders=content-m
  d5;content-type;host;x-amz-date, Signature=aa2c93b491918a742a53d4fdff03c8fb75aa776269ec625a48c0a089f63d069c....    
```

The Content-MD5 header makes it look somewhat like a v2 request, but the Authorization header is that of a v4 request.

The current workaround is to explicitly configure:

```
s3 =
    signature_version = s3v4
```

...in my profile, which causes a valid v4 request that includes a `x-amz-content-sha256` to be created as expected.

Currently using awscli 1.11.6

issues.title: Add arguments for waiter retry count and delay
issues.body: The `aws ecs wait` command tries for 10 minutes to wait for the condition to be satisfied. However, this sometimes is not enough time for the job to finish, it would be better to have a flag to set how many times to wait until the script throws an error.

issues.title: aws autoscaling wait for autoscaling operation completion
issues.body:
I have recently run across an issue like the following when trying to update the desired capacity on an autoscaling instance.

```
An error occurred (ScalingActivityInProgress) when calling the SetDesiredCapacity operation: Scaling activity b065594a-1c39-4c9a-8e5a-562c6b103df2 is in progress and blocks this action.
```

It would be nice if something like the aws ec2 wait .... functionality that was recently introduced could be applied, so that I would know when it was safe to attempt this type of change.

issues.title: Documentation: Warning about ec2 move-address-to-vpc
issues.body:
The documentation does not mention about move-address-to-vpc that the move can take a long time (currently I have an IP address still in MovingToVpc status for more than 24 hours), during which the IP can not be managed.

A simple warning in the documentation that moving an IP may take a long period of time would be of use to users.

issues.title: Support for colorized JSON output
issues.body:
It would be great if JSON output can be colorized to make viewing/working with JSON output easier. 

An example would be having all JSON keys in one color, strings values in another, and having number values in third. Very similar to what e.g http://www.bodurov.com/JsonFormatter/ would produce in terms of colors. Another example is: http://pygments.org/demo/5862267/

Possible one could simply approach coloring of JSON result by piping through e.g Pygments?
An example from SO (source: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25638905/coloring-json-output-in-python)

```
from pygments import highlight, lexers, formatters
colorful_json = highlight(unicode(formatted_json, 'UTF-8'), lexers.JsonLexer(), formatters.TerminalFormatter())
print(colorful_json)
```

issues.title: CodeCommit credential helper does not work on Python 3 in Windows
issues.body: Git wants unix style line endings from its credential helpers, but Python converts unix style line endings to windows-style line endings when writing strings to stdout. There is currently a fix for that behavior for python 2, which is to use `msvcrt.setmode` to set the line ending translation mode to `O_Binary`. That fix no longer works in python 3, so the cli will need to write to `stdout.buffer`.

issues.title: Support short form arguments for high level commands
issues.body:
For instance, instead of `aws s3 sync --quiet ...` we would have `aws s3 sync -q`.

We wouldn't be able to support these for every argument (`sync`, for instance, has five arguments that start with 'c'), but we could potentially cut down on some of the verbosity.

issues.title: No easy way to copy a single directory to s3
issues.body:
My apologies if this has been discussed before; I tried my best to search for it (difficult) and read through the relevant labels.

Given a directory with multiple things in it:

```
/tmp
├── aaa
    ├── foo
    ├── bar
├── bbb
├── ccc
```

I'd like to copy one of those directories to s3, the equivalent of `cp -r /tmp/aaa /my-bucket/`.

Unfortunately, both `aws s3 cp` and `aws s3 sync` act more like `cp -r /tmp/aaa/* /my-bucket/` - that is, they skip the containing directory and splat all its containing files directly into the root of the bucket.  Running either

```
[$]> aws s3 sync /tmp/aaa s3://my-bucket
```

or

```
[$]> aws s3 cp /tmp/aaa s3://my-bucket --recursive
```

will result in the _contents_ of `aaa` residing in s3:

```
my-bucket:
├── foo
├── bar
```

(For my particular purposes, I don't care about synchronization, but was just hoping that perhaps `sync` would act as I hoped.  Existing documentation aside, I would expect `aws s3 cp` to act like `cp` and `aws s3 sync` to act like `rsync`, in regards to directories, at least as far as can happen with s3's lack of actual directories.)

This is annoying, because it forces me to `basename` the directory and tack that on to the end of the bucket.  It's also surprising; not only does it not act like common *nix utilities, but `aws s3 sync help` implies a different behavior via its use of `.` as a source directory for all examples.

issues.title: S3 sync recursively with per-object metadata
issues.body:
I'm looking to take advantage of the `aws s3 sync` command, but provide per-object metadata (i.e. metadata that can change per object) rather than provide global metadata with `--metadata`.

Right now, I have basically a couple of options:
- Write my own syncing procedures. This would seem duplicative of the work/testing that has gone into the `sync` command.
- Include metadata in separate objects, e.g. /path/to/object and /path/to/object.meta. This isn't the greatest, means I have to pay extra and also manage the metadata within my application.
- Upload on a per-object basis. This isn't going to be performant for my use case.

What would be nice is if I could somehow indicate to the CLI that I want to map each object to a set of metadata, and then upload each object with that metadata. A couple of solutions come to mind:
- A giant JSON file mapping each key name to a metadata hash e.g.:

``` json
{
  "path/to/object1": {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2},
  ...etc...
}
```

``` shell
$ aws s3 sync /some/dir s3://somebucket --metadata-mapping /path/to/meta/mapping.json
```
- Some convention for writing metadata locally into a separate file per intended object, and having the `sync` command read the metadata for each object prior to uploading. For example, I could have a local directory:

``` shell
$ ls /path/to/local/files
file1
file1.meta
$ cat file1.meta
{
  "key1": "value1",
  "key2": "value2"
}
$ aws s3 sync /path/to/local/files s3://somebucket --object-metadata '$filename.meta'
```

(So when this is run, the `$filename.meta` files would just be read for metadata, and would not be transferred)
- A callback that takes the local filename as a parameter and spits out the metadata, e.g.

``` shell
$ ls /path/to/local/files
file1
$ lookup-metadata.py /path/to/local/files/file1
{
  "key1": "value1"
}
$ aws s3 sync /path/to/local/files s3://somebucket --metadata-callback lookup-metadata.py
```

Alternatively, what would be really great is if the syncing functionality were available independently of the CLI from within Python (without requiring me to figure out the internals of how to properly initialize the CLI environment, etc.), so that I could subclass and customize the process. I started going down this route somewhat, but am worried that this API is not for public consumption and would break in the future.

Any thoughts?

issues.title: Allow customization of directory where cached credential data is stored
issues.body:
Currently, this directory is statically encoded as a subdirectory under `~/.aws`. However, it would be nice (for security reasons) to be able to store these credentials in another location. For example, when using MIT Kerberos on Linux, TGTs are stored in `/tmp`, and you can set the `KRB5CCNAME` env var to customize the filename of the active TGT cache (including changing the directory) (see `kinit(1)` man page).

Alternatively, as another example, it would be nice to store them in a directory in shared memory (e.g. `/dev/shm`) so that if the machine is powered off, the credentials would not persist.

issues.title: No way to wait for an s3 key to be updated
issues.body:
I have a process that writes updated versions of a file to the same S3 key on a regular basis. The [FAQ](https://aws.amazon.com/s3/faqs#What_data_consistency_model_does_Amazon_S3_employ) states that in this scenario, S3 only guarantees eventual consistency (i.e., an immediate read after the PUT command succeeds is not guaranteed to return the updated version). I would like to use the `s3api wait object-exists` command to wait for the key to be updated, so that I know that the change has propagated.

However, it seems that the the `--if*` conditions ( --if-match, --if-modified-since, --if-none-match, --if-unmodified-since) were not designed for this use case. If the condition isn't met, they return immediately. I would expect `s3api wait` to imply that the process would honor its contract ( "Wait until 200 response is received when polling with head-object. It will poll every 5 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks."), and only then exit with the failed HTTP status code (304 or 412).

Ideally, what I would like to do is this, where the previous contents of the key's `LastModified` was `2016-04-20T12:34:09.000Z`:

```
aws s3api wait object-exists --bucket my-bucket --key path/to/my/key --if-modified-since $(date '+%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ')
```

This command would not return until it had exhausted the 20 checks for the incremented `LastModified` value. If the value has been updated (either before the wait command started or during execution), then exit with status 0. If it hasn't changed after 20 checks, then exit status 255. Currently, the process returns immediately:

```
aws s3api wait object-exists --bucket my-bucket --key path/to/my/key --if-modified-since "2016-04-21T12:34:09Z" 

Waiter ObjectExists failed: Not Modified
```

issues.title: Add support for cognito cred provider
issues.body:
This is a feature request.

I would be great if AWS-CLI handles tedious cognito unauth user flow behind the scene, just like sts `assume-role`.
## implicit cognito-identity API calls

Currently, if you want to access AWS resources via cognito unauth users, you have to call two `cognito-identity` APIs.
1. `cognito-identity`  to get ids
2. `get-credentials-for-identity`  to get temporary credentials.

After that, set credentials for the next API calls.

If AWS-CLI handles these auth flow, shell scripts become much simpler.
## file-caching cognito credentials

cognito unauth users really fit with IoT devices since you don't need to distribute credentials,
and I don't want these devices to incur extra communication costs.
Just like sts assume-role, local-caching cognito credentials reduces cognito-wise API calls.
## new style

```
$ cat ~/.aws/credentials
[profile foo]
identity-pool-id = ... <- new attributes for unauth cognito user
$ aws s3 cp foo s3://bucket/foo --profile foo # If there's no cognito credentials, get cred via cognito-identity APIs before calling S3 command.
$ aws s3 cp bar s3://bucket/bar --profile foo # use local-cached cognito credential
```
## old style

```
$ aws cognito-identity get-id --identity-pool-id XXX --region eu-west-1
{
    "IdentityId": "YYY"
}
$ aws cognito-identity get-credentials-for-identity --identity-id XXX --region eu-west-1
{
    "Credentials": {
        "SecretKey": "AAA",

issues.title: $ ec2 copy-snapshot --no-encrypted raises InvalidParameterValue error.
issues.body:
I think this is a server side bug.
# Problem

`ec2 copy-snapshot` has an option(`--encrypted`) to encrypt non-encrypted EBS snapshots. (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/copy-snapshot.html)

```
$ aws ec2 copy-snapshot --source-region ap-northeast-1 --source-snapshot-id <SNAPSHOTID> --description XXX --encrypted
```

According to the API doc(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_CopySnapshot.html), this flag(`Encrypted`) is boolean and AWS-CLI supports `--encrypted` _and_ `--no-encrypted` flags.

But if you pass `--no-encrypted` option, `InvalidParameterValue` error is raised.

```
$ aws ec2 copy-snapshot --source-region ap-northeast-1 --source-snapshot-id <SNAPSHOTID> --description XXX --no-encrypted --debug
...
GET
/
Action=CopySnapshot&Description=encrypted%20snapshot&DestinationRegion=ap-northeast-1&Encrypted=false&...
...
A client error (InvalidParameterValue) occurred when calling the CopySnapshot operation: -10022: The parameter encrypted=false is invalid
```

This error occurs against both encrypted and unencrypted snapshots.
# Expected result
- [ok]`--encrypted` => copied snapshots are encrypted.
- [gray zone]`--no-encrypted` => copied snapshots are unencrypted.But decrypting encrypted EBS snapshots are not supported(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-copy-snapshot.html), so this flag is meaningless against encrypted snapshots. For such case, server side should raise errors, I think. What do you think?
- [ok]no Encrypted flag provided => as-is. Keep encrypted state

issues.title: Need high level API for Glacier multipart-upload
issues.body:
Glacier supports multipart uploads just like S3, and do the following steps.
1. initiate multipart-upload
2. multipart uploads
3. complete-multipart-upload

The hard part is #3.
`glacier complete-multipart-upload` command requires `--checksum` which is the SHA256 tree hash of the entire archive, but there is no easy way to compute this checksum with shell scripts.
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/glacier/complete-multipart-upload.html

It would be great if `glacier` has high level `cp` command and

```
if FILESIZE < MULTIPART_THRESHOLD: 
    basic upload-archive
else:
    multipart-upload
```

As you know, `s3 cp` command works this way(8MB threshold is used there).

review_comments.body:
I got the same error in a newly created environment and I think I found the culprit.

The problem stems from how integration test is executed.

As you can see in `tests/integration/__init__.py` line #21-#24, integration tests are executed by running `CWD/bin/aws` command, and when they are run, module `awscli` is imported not from `CWD/awscli` but from system default module search path.

That's why new test case(added to demonstrate the current problem) fails.

Following hackish code forces integration tests to be executed using `CWD/awscli` module.

```
$ diff --git a/awscli/clidriver.py b/awscli/clidriver.py
index 6a7da73..3e20f96 100644
--- a/awscli/clidriver.py
+++ b/awscli/clidriver.py
@@ -535,3 +535,6 @@ class CLIOperationCaller(object):
             output = self._session.get_variable('output')
         formatter = get_formatter(output, args)
         formatter(operation, response)
+
+if __name__ == '__main__':
+    main()
diff --git a/tests/integration/__init__.py b/tests/integration/__init__.py
index fdde492..d8cca93 100644
--- a/tests/integration/__init__.py
+++ b/tests/integration/__init__.py
@@ -82,6 +82,7 @@ def aws(command, collect_memory=False, env_vars=None,
         aws_command = os.environ['AWS_TEST_COMMAND']
     else:
         aws_command = 'python %s' % AWS_CMD
+        aws_command = 'python -m awscli.clidriver'
     full_command = '%s %s' % (aws_command, command)
     stdout_encoding = _get_stdout_encoding()
     if isinstance(full_command, six.text_type) and not six.PY3:
```

With this patch, I can run tests without error:

```
$ nosetests tests/integration/customizations/s3/test_plugin.py:TestWebsiteConfiguration
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 4.730s

OK
```

issues.title: Shorthand parser does not handle '/', which apigateway documentation suggests is allowed
issues.body:
The API documentation for [`aws apigateway put-method`](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/apigateway/put-method.html) suggests that using shorthand syntax is allowed for the `--request-models` parameter. The schema for this parameter is described as follows:

> Request models are represented as a key/value map, with a content type as the key and a Model name as the value

Because the key in this case is a content type such as `application/json`, I think it seems reasonable to expect that the shorthand syntax will work with the following:

``` bash
aws apigateway put-method \
  --rest-api-id "$api_id" \
  --resource-id "$resource_id" \
  --http-method POST \
  --authorization-type NONE \
  --request-models "application/json=Hookshot"
```

However, this results in the following error:

``` bash
Error parsing parameter '--request-models': Expected: '=', received: '/' for input:
application/json=Hookshot
           ^
```

Looking at the shorthand parser, the error makes sense, as `/` doesn't appear to be an allowed character. Should it be? If not, it should the documentation be updated to not suggest using the shorthand syntax, given that it will pretty much be impossible to use for any content type?

Thanks!

issues.title: Provide an option to perfom unicode normalization on local file names
issues.body: ## Summary `aws s3 sync` doesn't play well with HFS+ unicode normalization on OS X. I suggest to add an option to normalize file names read locally in normal form C before doing anything with them. ## Reproduction steps 1. Create a file on S3 containing an accented character. For reasons that will become apparent later, do this on a Linux system. ``` (linux) % echo test > test/café.txt (linux) % aws s3 sync test s3:///test ``` 2. Synchronize that file on a Mac. ``` (OS X) % aws s3 sync s3:///test test download: s3:///test/café.txt to test/café.txt ``` 3. Synchronize it back to S3. ``` (OS X) % aws s3 sync s3:///test test upload: test/café.txt to s3:///test/café.txt ``` - Expected result: no upload because the file is identical locally and on S3: I was just sync'd! - Actual result: the file is uploaded again. At this point the file shows up twice in S3! ## Why this happens Unicode defines two normal forms — NFC and NFD — for some characters, typically accented characters which are common in Western European languages and even occur in English. The documentation of [unicodedata.normalize](https://docs.python.org/3/library/unicodedata.html#unicodedata.normalize), the Python function that converts between the two forms, has a good explanation. A quick illustration: ``` >>> "café".encode('utf-8') >>> b'caf\xc3\xa9' >>> unicodedata.normalize('NFC', "café").encode('utf-8') >>> b'caf\xc3\xa9' >>> unicodedata.normalize('NFD', "café").encode('utf-8') >>> b'cafe\xcc\x81' ``` The default filesystem of OS X, [HFS+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HFS_Plus), enforces something that resembles NFD. (Let's say I haven't encountered the difference yet.) Pretty much everything else, including typing on a keyboard on Linux or OS X, uses NFC. I'm not sure about Windows. Of course this is entirely HFS+'s fault, but since OS X is a popular system among your target audience, I hope you may have some interest in providing a solution to this problem. **What you can do about it** I think a `--normalize-unicode` option (possibly with a better name) for `aws s3 sync` would be useful. It would normalize file names read from the local filesystem with `unicodedata.normalize('NFKC', filepath)`. Its primary purpose would be to interact with S3 on OS X and have file names in NFC form on S3, which is what the rest of the world expects and will cause the least amount of problems. I don't know `aws cli` well enough to tell which other parts could use this option. I just encountered the problem when trying to replace "`rsync` to file server" with "`aws s3 sync` to S3". FWIW `rsync` provides a solution to this problem with the `--iconv` option. A common idiom is `--iconv=UTF8-MAC,UTF8` when rsync'ing from OS X to Linux and `--iconv=UTF8,UTF8-MAC` when rsync'ing from Linux to OS X. `UTF8-MAC` is how `rsync` calls the encoding of file names on HFS+. However this isn't a good API to tackle the specific problem I'm raising here. This API is about the encoding of file names. The bug is related to Unicode normalization. These are different concepts. `UTF8-MAC` mixes them. Thanks!

issues.title: Valid MFA token does not work during first 1am hour before daylight savings ends and second 1am hour starts
issues.body:
I have a number of aws-cli config profiles that let me assume cross-account roles with MFA token. The configs take this form:

```
[profile name]
role_arn = arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/rolename
mfa_serial = arn:aws:iam::987654321098:mfa/myname
source_profile = default
region = us-east-1
```

These roles have worked fine for weeks, but are now giving me an error when I enter the valid MFA code.

```
$ aws s3 ls
Enter MFA code: 
Cannot refresh credentials: MFA token required.
```

Interestingly, it gives me a different error if I enter an invalid MFA code (or the same valid code twice):

```
$ aws s3 ls
Enter MFA code: 
A client error (AccessDenied) occurred when calling the AssumeRole operation:
MultiFactorAuthentication failed with invalid MFA one time pass code. 
```

This problem is occurring with two source accounts (different MFA devices) and multiple target accounts, all of which worked hours ago.

I am able to use the same MFA devices to sign in to the same AWS accounts through the AWS console, and to assume the same cross-account roles.

Tonight is the night that daylight savings ends in my timezone, but that doesn't happen for another 5 minutes at which point I will repeat the 1am hour. No idea if that could affect it or not.

issues.title: SSL connection fails on big files (may be related to VPC S3 endpoint)
issues.body:
Hi, we recently added a VPC S3 endpoint to our VPC. Since then uploads of large files are failing at around the 10GB mark, but it varies.

See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/vpc-endpoints.html for details of VPC endpoints.

We then tried disabling SSL. The uploads now work, but at around the 10GB mark (and with debug turned on), we can see the awscli is getting (and auto retrying) socket.error exceptions, code 104, "Connection reset by peer".

So there are two probems:
1) awscli does not cope with connection reset by peer errors when using SSL.
2) The VPC s3 endpoint is somehow causing socket.error exceptions to appear.

In the logs, I've manually masked the filenames as they are client sensitive.  

We're using aws-cli/1.8.5 Python/2.7.9 Linux/3.19.0-25-generic on ubuntu 15.04 from an amazon VPC instance in eu-west-1a

issues.title: aws s3 rb --force deletes buckets of contents even if explicitly forbidden to delete bucket
issues.body:
I'm hoping to learn if this is expected behavior or a bug. Even after an explicit bucket policy that prevents a user from deleting a bucket, they can still run `rb --force` and delete the contents of the bucket. The command is aware that the user doesn't have permissions to remove the bucket but still allows it to recursively delete the files.

It seems to me the expected behavior should be to check for delete permissions on the bucket first, and then proceed with a recursive to delete if the user has permission to delete the bucket.
## How to reproduce

Create a test bucket and apply the following bucket policy

```
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Id": "foo",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Sid": "Stmt1437437343806",
            "Effect": "Deny",
            "Principal": "*",
            "Action": "s3:DeleteBucket",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::mybucket"
        }
    ]
}
```

Fill the bucket with files and then run the `aws s3 rb --force s3://mybucket` command. Despite it knowing it's forbidden from deleting the bucket, it will clear out all of the files recursively.

```
$ for i in `seq 1 10`; do touch test${i}; aws s3 cp test${i} s3://zz-placeholder33/;done
$ aws s3 rb s3://zz-placeholder33/
remove_bucket failed: s3://zz-placeholder33/ A client error (AccessDenied) occurred when calling the DeleteBucket operation: Access Denied
$ dataeng@cron-gateway[2032]~: aws s3 rb --force s3://zz-placeholder33/
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test5
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test9
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test1
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test2
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test10
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test3
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test4
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test8
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test6
delete: s3://zz-placeholder33/test7
remove_bucket failed: s3://zz-placeholder33/ A client error (AccessDenied) occurred when calling the DeleteBucket operation: Access Denied
```

issues.title: Change bold color or persistenly set --color off

The default "bold" display is dark blue. This contrast is hard to read against dark/black background colors as is default in most operating systems. This is even worse for visually impaired people.

The only known workaround is to disable color by specifying the "--color off" option. This however is tedious to retype for every command. It would be safe to assume users would not decide on this on a command-by-command basis and would prefer persistent or at a minimum per session decision on this.

Any, or all, of the following options should help alleviate the issue:

1) provide environment variable to specify "--color off"
2) provide .aws config file option to specify default --color option
3) provide method to set custom colors for text/bold text
4) change the default color to something other than the current dark blue.

issues.title: aws deploy push Command = Add Support for "--query" and "--output"
issues.body:
## Current Behavior:

when running aws deploy push the command returns output as follows:
`To deploy with this revision, run:`
`aws deploy create-deployment --application-name codedeploy --s3-location bucket=codedeploy-codedeploybucket-1ajnq59aekkfj,key=codedeploy_1.0,bundleType=zip,eTag="77021852995a5e7be590c7dc8a2227fd" --deployment-group-name <deployment-group-name> --deployment-config-name <deployment-config-name> --description <description>`
## Desired Behavior:

For use in writing command line scripts, I'd like to be able to control the output using the `--query` option and "--output" command that is supported by other `awscli` commands. An example, I would run command:
`aws deploy push --application-name codedeploy --s3-location s3://$codedeploy_s3_bucket/codedeploy_${revision} --source ./ --region $region --query s3-location.key[eTag]`
And I would get returned:
`77021852995a5e7be590c7dc8a2227fd`
## Summary:

My feeling is that output from the command should be able to be controlled by the `--query` argument so that subsequent execution of the program allows us to use output in subsequent commands.

issues.title: [BUG] [aws deploy] 'latin1' code character causes error when displaying data
issues.body:

issues.title: [NFR] [aws deploy push] Add Support for Server Side Encryption [--sse] (Mirrors aws s3 cp)

issues.title: Filename encoding errors
issues.body:
Hello all

I'm using `aws s3 sync` to upload to a bucket, but I'm getting errors on many files:

```
    Please check your locale settings.  The filename was decoded as: ANSI_X3.4-1968
    On posix platforms, check the LC_CTYPE environment variable.
```

My system is Ubuntu Server 14.04 running aws-cli 1.7.5 and Python 2.7.6. I've altered my installations locale to `en_US.UTF-8` using `export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8`, but that didn't change anything. The filesystem is ext4, and the files in question have been created by OSX via Netatalk 3.1.7 (AFP).

Any suggestions very much welcome...

issues.title: Unable to set `charset` when mime-types are guessed (S3)
issues.body:
We are syncing a directory of various file types to an S3 bucket and `aws-cli` is correctly guessing the mime-types, however in our case it's important that it also append the `charset`. For example the guessed content-type for `index.html` might look like this:

```
Content-Type: text/html
```

But we'd like a way to be able to tell `aws-cli` that the `charset` for all the synced files is `UTF8` for instance:

```
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
```

Version: `aws-cli/1.7.26 Python/2.7.6 Darwin/14.4.0`

issues.title: Missing aws ec2 wait internet-gateway-deleted is needed
issues.body:
The following script fails without `sleep 1` (or an appropriate loop) in order to give AWS enough time to delete the internet gateway
### delete.sh

``` shell
#!/bin/sh
source ~/.bashrc

echo '------------------------------------------------------------'
echo '>>> vpc deletion'

if [ -z "$1" ]
then
    echo '>>> missig arguments'
    exit
fi

VPC_CIDR=$1
echo '>>> deleting vpc' $VPC_CIDR

# http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/describe-vpcs.html
VPC_ID=$(aws ec2 describe-vpcs --query "Vpcs[?CidrBlock=='$VPC_CIDR'].[VpcId][0][0]" --output text)
echo '>>>' $VPC_ID 'found'

if [ "$VPC_ID" == "None" ]
then
    echo '>>>' $VPC_CIDR 'vpc already deleted'
else

    # TODO this script only works with one attachment only between gateway and vpc
    # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/describe-internet-gateways.html
    IGW_ID=$(aws ec2 describe-internet-gateways --query "InternetGateways[].{ InternetGatewayId: InternetGatewayId, VpcId: Attachments[0].VpcId } | [?VpcId == '$VPC_ID'].[InternetGatewayId][0][0]" --output text)

    if [ -z $IGW_ID ]
    then
        echo '>>>' $VPC_CIDR 'has no internet gateway'
    else

        echo '>>>' $IGW_ID 'internet gateway found'

        # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/detach-internet-gateway.html
        aws ec2 detach-internet-gateway --internet-gateway-id "$IGW_ID" --vpc-id "$VPC_ID"
        echo '>>>' $IGW_ID 'internet gateway detached'

        # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/delete-internet-gateway.html
        aws ec2 delete-internet-gateway --internet-gateway-id "$IGW_ID"
        echo '>>>' $IGW_ID 'internet gateway deleted'

    fi

    # TODO we need a waiter here
    sleep 1

    # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/describe-subnets.html
    VPC_SUBNETS=$(aws ec2 describe-subnets --query "Subnets[?VpcId=='$VPC_ID'].[SubnetId][]" --output text)
    echo '>>>' $VPC_SUBNETS 'subnets found'

    for SUBNET_ID in $VPC_SUBNETS
    do
        echo '>>> deleting' $SUBNET_ID
        # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/delete-subnet.html
        aws ec2 delete-subnet --subnet-id "$SUBNET_ID"
    done
    echo '>>>' $VPC_SUBNETS 'subnets deleted'

    # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/ec2/delete-vpc.html
    aws ec2 delete-vpc --vpc-id "$VPC_ID"
    echo '>>>' $VPC_CIDR 'vpc deleted'
fi
```

issues.title: aws ec2 wait conversion-task-completed times out
issues.body:
I'm trying to migrate to the unified cli, and to use waiters instead of polling loops, but the conversion-task-completed waiter consistently times out in us-east-1 for my 12GB disk.

It reports 
Waiter ConversionTaskCompleted failed: Max attempts exceeded
but the task does complete successfully. I can write a loop which calls the waiter, but I'd prefer to increase the number of attempts, or reduce their frequency. They appear to be taken from botocore/data/aws/ec2/2014-09-01.waiters.json, which contains the following:

"ConversionTaskCompleted": {      "delay": 15,      "operation":
"DescribeConversionTasks",      "maxAttempts": 40,

I'd like these to be exposed as parameters in the aws cli command, or perhaps for the timeout to be derived from the size of the disk being converted.

issues.title: S3 Sync Deleting Excluded Files
issues.body: I have a simple bash script setup which syncs from a local server to an S3 bucket and then from the S3 bucket to the local server. The idea is that several local servers can sync up to the cloud and then retrieve any updates from other servers following their own update. I am using the following commands: aws s3 sync s3://bucket-name/home /home --delete --exclude "~*" --exclude "*~" aws s3 sync /home s3://bucket-name/home --delete --exclude "~*" --exclude "*~" The first is to upload all changed files whilst ignoring any temporary files and the second is to download any newer files from the cloud whilst ignoring temporary files (not really required as they should never get uploaded). My problem is that it will upload perfectly well, ignoring the temporary files and deleting out the files that no longer exist on the server, but when syncing back down it downloads any updated files correctly but then starts deleting out the temporary files because they aren't in the S3 bucket. It would appear that the --exclude option doesn't encompass the whole sync operation. It's as if the exclude is ignored and such files marked to be excluded from the sync are included for the purpose of the delete option. I've tried putting the --delete option after the --exclude but it then ignores the excludes and syncs everything. Would appreciate any help with regards to a correct syntax or confirming this is a bug.

issues.title: use libmagic (filemagic) to guess content type if mimetypes.guess_type() fails
issues.body:
Right now commands such as `aws s3 cp` attempt to guess the file type using  `mimetypes.guess_type()`, which will fail for files that aren't registered mime types on the system.

`filemagic` could be tried if this fails, it uses libmagic (just like the unix `file` command) and will try reading the first few bytes of the file to see if it can be identified.

It would be nice to be able to invoke this as a fallback for when `mimetypes.guess_type()` returns `None`, perhaps as an option (disabled by default) because it incurs some overhead on each of the source files.

issues.title: aws ec2 modify-instance-attribute lack examples and inconsistent format for user-data
issues.body:
I've run into a problem regarding documentation and probably `aws ec2 behavior with modify-instance-attribute`, there doesn't seem to have a way to inform that my input is already base64-encoded.

Also, the documentation does not have an example of usage regarding --user-data flag, when I try to send a multiline value (as I need to because my input is an YAML) it obviously will break the JSON structure and converting my input is non-trivial (I have to `sed` it before to change line breaks into control characters).

It would be great to have a flag inside the JSON structure that my input is already base64-encoded. Also, this input differs from `aws ec2 run-instances` which expects a base64-encoded string and not a JSON structure.

issues.title: Does aws s3 sync will loss metadata sometimes?
issues.body:
## Scenario 1:

```
`aws s3 sync s3://files/ s3://files-backup --recursive --profile <user_name>`
```
- sync files between two buckets under the same account and the same region, some files' metadata lost with key like `x-amz-meta-json`
## Scenario 2:

```
`aws s3 sync s3://files-dev/ s3://files-prod --recursive --profile <user_name>`
```
- sync files between two buckets which is belong to two account and the same region, for example, one account is for development and the other one is for production, some files' metadata also lost with key like `x-amz-meta-json`. 
  
  Note: the batch of files which lost metadata are the same in the two scenarios above.
  
  Does anyone has the same issue?

issues.title: aws s3 sync doesn't allow file for source argument
issues.body:
I'm interested in using the 'aws s3 sync' command as a sort of conditional 'aws s3 cp'.

I have a local file which may or may not exist in the target s3 bucket, and I **only** want to do the upload if:
- the destination either doesn't exist,
- doesn't have the same length,
- or doesn't have the same MD5 hash.

The 'sync' command really seems to fit the bill. Unfortunately it seems that with the 'sync' command you can only specify a **directory** for source/destination:

```
$ aws s3 sync --dryrun somefile s3://somebucket/somedir/
warning: Skipping file /home/snoonan/somefile/. File does not exist.
Completed 0 part(s) with ... file(s) remaining
```

The following change makes it work, but introduces some new edge cases that need errors:

``` patch
diff --git a/awscli/customizations/s3/fileformat.py b/awscli/customizations/s3/fileformat.py
index fc2caca..93e475c 100644
--- a/awscli/customizations/s3/fileformat.py
+++ b/awscli/customizations/s3/fileformat.py
@@ -82,7 +82,7 @@ class FileFormat(object):
                be of the one provided.
         """
         full_path = os.path.abspath(path)
-        if (os.path.exists(full_path) and os.path.isdir(full_path)) or dir_op:
+        if os.path.exists(full_path) and os.path.isdir(full_path):
             full_path += os.sep
             return full_path, True
         else:
diff --git a/awscli/customizations/s3/filegenerator.py b/awscli/customizations/s3/filegenerator.py
index 1d587ed..d3d24e2 100644
--- a/awscli/customizations/s3/filegenerator.py
+++ b/awscli/customizations/s3/filegenerator.py
@@ -156,10 +156,7 @@ class FileGenerator(object):
         join, isdir, isfile = os.path.join, os.path.isdir, os.path.isfile
         error, listdir = os.error, os.listdir
         if not self.should_ignore_file(path):
-            if not dir_op:
-                size, last_update = get_file_stat(path)
-                yield path, size, last_update
-            else:
+            if dir_op and os.path.isdir(path):
                 # We need to list files in byte order based on the full
                 # expanded path of the key: 'test/1/2/3.txt'  However,
                 # listdir() will only give us contents a single directory
@@ -193,6 +190,9 @@ class FileGenerator(object):
                     else:
                         size, last_update = get_file_stat(file_path)
                         yield file_path, size, last_update
+            else:
+                size, last_update = get_file_stat(path)
+                yield path, size, last_update

     def normalize_sort(self, names, os_sep, character):
         """
```

It doesn't work correctly if, for example, the source is an S3 directory path and the destination is a local file (rather than local directory). Instead of erroring out, it would overwrite the destination file multiple times with each file from the source bucket.

I also notice that the function at awscli/customizations/s3/subcommands.py:918 (check_src_path) didn't throw an exception after my change. Assuming it's not dead code, I'd expect it to try to validate my arguments and realize that my source is a file, while dir_op=True, and thus the exception on 941 would be thrown. Weird.

issues.title: Add support to s3 sync for symlinks as website redirects

With the addition of website redirects several years ago, is there any reason not to support syncing symlinked files as a redirect?  Symlink directories could also be supported via managing the bucket redirection rules.

Relatedly, the "--website-redirect (string)" option is listed as part of the help output for the sync command, but a single string makes no sense for an operation that can work on an arbitrary number of files.  If what I'm looking for is supported via this option somehow, some usage examples are needed.

issues.title: aws dynamodb update-item adding unnecessary base64 encoding to binary attributes
Could strip whitespace from env var credentials
issues.body:
I just debugged a problem with a bash script that uses the CLI tools with env vars for the credential config. It reads the creds from text files (for legacy reasons) using cat. This fails because of a trailing '\r' that sneaks into the var:

```
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=`cat ${AWS_SECRETS}/aws_access_key`
```

The solution is to add the following, which strips the bad character:

```
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=${AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID%$'\r'}
```

But it would be handy if the CLI tools stripped leading/trailing cruft from input strings/envvars (as the old Java based tools must have done: I'm porting these bash scripts from the Java tools to these python ones, and it used to work with the old CLI tools).

issues.title: providing functionality equivalent to EC2 CLI's import-instance?
issues.body:
I can't figure out any way that the aws-cli provides the ability to import / upload a VM image for use as an EC2 instance, ultimately for the purpose of creating a custom AMI.

Given that [various sources](http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/vm-import/) of [EC2 documentation](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/UsingVirtualMachinesinAmazonEC2.html) communicate only the EC2 CLI mechanism - i.e. [ec2-import-instance](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-ImportInstance.html) - I'm left to conclude that aws-cli does not provide equivalent functionality. If that's true, **(1) why not?** and **(2) will it ever?**

While not _explicitly_ stating this, the [AWS Command Line Tools listing](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/GetTheTools.html) implies that this aws-cli tool provides the necessary functionality formerly provided via the tools listed under the "Previous" (i.e. deprecated?) header. I may be reading too much into that language, but fwiw, that's how I'm reading it.

(Apologies if I've duplicated an existing issue. I just searched for 'import' and none of the results appeared to be related.)

issues.title: Support aws s3 cp from Query String Authentication URLs
issues.body:
We control access to our files stored on S3 externally from our web application by sending a 302 redirect to a [signed url](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/RESTAuthentication.html#RESTAuthenticationQueryStringAuth), generated using [boto.s3.connection.S3Connection.generate_url](http://boto.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ref/s3.html#boto.s3.connection.S3Connection.generate_url).

Many of our files are large (multi-GB genome sequence data) and we'd like to allow users to download these using `aws s3 cp` as we've found it to be significantly faster than alternative parallel download utilities such as `pcurl.sh` and `lftp`.

Ideally this would support following a 302 redirect to the signed URL, so that our users could simply run:

```
$ aws s3 cp "https://user:pass@example.com/redirect-to-signed-s3-url" .
```

issues.title: s3 sync does not preserve permissions across buckets
issues.body:
When I sync across buckets with a command of:

aws s3 sync s3://bucket1 s3://bucket2

I would expect the files in bucket2 to have the same permissions as the files in bucket1 by default as it is a "sync"

Instead they only have the default permissions.

issues.title: s3 sync: ability to compare based on filename alone
issues.body:
I was going to move from using s3cmd to the official was-cli, however there's one feature that appears to be missing that I use. The `--skip-existing` option.
During a sync operation, this would only copy a file if there wasn't a target file of the same name (regardless of size or md5 comparison).

Is there any comparable method within the existing toolset or is this a feature request?

issues.title: Human readable statistics for transfers
issues.body:
Feature request:  

add the ability to have AWS CLI report statistics about transfers, sizes, xfer time totals, etc., in human readable (and perhaps formats for parsing) that can be used to generate reports about activity -- or be used as the report itself, using user-selectable fields/options and formatting.

The debugging output is way too verbose for this purpose, it's also in XML.  

I can see where this capability would be very useful to sysadmins, etc.

issues.title: Check if profile exists command
issues.body:
We use several different profiles for uploading our static website to different environments, each environment has it's own profile. It would be nice to have a way to check if a profile is configured and if not prompt the user to configure the profile, it could even be an extra parameter for the configure command, ex. `aws configure --skip-exists`

We have a deployment bash script that configures your environment, including installing awscli via pip, this would be a nice addition to that script

issues.title: Feature request: pass whole JSON blog
issues.body:
It would be great if this worked:

aws --profile amp dynamodb describe-table --table-name smart-dcb-messages | aws --profile kapp dynamodb create-table

Currently to achieve this requires parsing the output of the describe command into individual blocks which most likely will just be concatenated on the other end anyhow ... 

It would also be good if the parser for create could gracefully handle the output of describe:

  aws --profile kapp dynamodb create-table \
    --attribute-definitions  `cat /tmp/dynamo.json | jq -c .Table.AttributeDefinitions` \
    --table-name             `cat /tmp/dynamo.json | jq -c .Table.TableName` \
    --key-schema             `cat /tmp/dynamo.json | jq -c .Table.KeySchema` \
    --provisioned-throughput `cat /tmp/dynamo.json | jq -c .Table.ProvisionedThroughput`

  Unknown key 'NumberOfDecreasesToday' for param 'ProvisionedThroughput'.  Must be one of: ReadCapacityUnits, WriteCapacityUnits

issues.title: EBS - how to know when RequestEnvironmentInfo has finished?
issues.body:
Is there any way to receive some kind of notification for when the command request-environment-info has finished requesting the information? I have written a shell script which uses this command and it seems to take a second or two so I don't know how long to wait until I can then call retrieve-environment-info.

Thanks,

issues.title: Better documentation for UserData in request-spot-instances
issues.body:
Using file://xxx as UserData in launch-specification doesn't seem to work. AWS console gives me "Bad base64 encoding" error. But when I tried to pass base64 encoded string to it, it worked.
Also I noted that previous posts said that file:// works and CLI will do base64 for us. But it's not the case.
I recommend clearer documentation (both in man page and in AWS website) about this.

issues.title: Install aws-cli using Homebrew
issues.body:
My [awscli formula](https://github.com/hydrajump/homebrew/blob/ec1379d4df6e436142ef3f84d56eb68a62dd7ffa/Library/Formula/awscli.rb) has been merged and is officially available with [Homebrew](http://brew.sh/).

It would be useful to add Homebrew as an installation option in the README.

As a suggestion something like this,
## Homebrew on Mac OS X

aws-cli can also be installed using the [Homebrew](http://brew.sh/) package manager on Mac OS X:

`brew install awscli`

If you want the development version of aws-cli:

`brew install awscli --HEAD`

After installation brew will provide instructions for installing completion and where to find the examples on how to use aws-cli.

Also test for the OSError case.

This restores the original test for skipped files, verifying that an
OSError (including FileNotFoundError) is also being caught correctly.

For clarity about the distinction, also add comments explaining the now
two tests.

Also catch ValueError when handling deleted files

This try/except tries to handle failed stat calls due to files not being
there. However, before it can do so, get_file_stat has already
transformed any IOError into a ValueError. This is presumably necessary
for Python versions < 3.3 where there is no distinct FileNotFoundError,
so we can't just delete that mapping.

Fixes #2960.

Fix the functional sync test for deleted files

get_file_stats actually returns a ValueError, not an IOError.
Additionally, IOError doesn't really exist anymore in Python 3.3+.

Bucket names switched in example

In the example, you sync from mybucket to mybucket2, not the other way around.
Fix broken nested list in config-vars.rst
Raise minimum required s3transfer version

Remove reference to no-longer-updated release notes

The link for the release notes at https://aws.amazon.com/releasenotes/?tag=releasenotes%23keywords%23cli states that release notes are now tracked in GitHub.
Remove extra double-quotation mark from example

pull_requests.title: Add --preserve-symlinks option for "deploy push" command
pull_requests.body:
By default, symlinks are materialized into their targets when they are zipped for deploy. Some applications, e.g. PHP's Doctrine ORM vendor/bin scripts, rely on symlinks to be preserved to work, and are thus broken by the default deploy behavior if your PHP project's deployment archive includes its vendor directory (which it should).

This commit adds an option (default off for BC reasons) to preserve symlinks when creating the deployment archive. Used --ignore-hidden-files as a template for parameter implementation.

Tests have been updated with the extra argument, including asserting that you can't specify to both preserve and not preserve symlinks simultaneously. However, while I've confirmed that behavior works as expected in the scenario for which I needed this functionality, there isn't an automated test to that effect, partially because I'm not sure how that test would fare across all environments.

References:
https://gist.github.com/kgn/610907
http://www.mail-archive.com/python-list@python.org/msg34223.html

pull_requests.title: Some editing and formatting (mostly literals).

(Installation_).

pull_requests.title: [SAM] Makes S3 Bucket parameter optional and creates bucket automatically in the deployment region
pull_requests.body:
Hi everyone,

 This PR makes it possible to omit `--s3-bucket` and AWS CLI will create a S3 bucket in the deployment region specified - This makes the following possible:

* Ability to launch the same SAM template in multiple regions
* Error out earlier if S3 Bucket and Deployment region differs instead of waiting for Cloudformation to be deployed and fail
* Ability to automatically create S3 Bucket if no `--s3-bucket` was passed

 This is a non-breaking change and those who are currently using `--s3-bucket` should continue to work just fine.

**Usage: Deploy SAM stack in Ireland region without specifying the bucket**

```bash
aws cloudformation package \
    --template-file template.yaml \
    --output-template-file packaged.yaml \
    --region eu-west-1 

aws cloudformation deploy \
    --template-file template.yaml \
    --stack-name test-sam \
    --region eu-west-1 \
    --capabilities CAPABILITY_IAM 
```

> **This will create a bucket named `sam-<region>-<accountId>`**

cc'ing contributors @sthulb @igngar

pull_requests.title: UTF-8 is default file encoding to read
pull_requests.body:
## My Environment

* Windows 7 Pro, Japanese (CP932)
* git bash 2.13.0
* AWS CLI via pip (aws-cli/1.11.109 Python/3.6.1 Windows/7 botocore/1.5.72)

## Problem

`aws cloudformation create-stack --template-body 'file://template.yml' --debug` raises an error.
template.yml is UTF-8 encoding.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "...\python36\lib\site-packages\awscli\paramfile.py", line 120, in get_file
    return f.read()
UnicodeDecodeError: 'cp932' codec can't decode byte 0x83 in position 68: illegal multibyte sequence
```

`get_file` calls `compat_open`, and `compat_open` opens file with platform dependent encoding, 'cp932' in Japanese environment, although the file is UTF-8 encoding.

```
$ python -i
Python 3.6.1 (v3.6.1:69c0db5, Mar 21 2017, 18:41:36) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import locale
>>> locale.getpreferredencoding()
'cp932'
```

## How to fix

1. UTF-8 is default file encoding to read in `get_file`
2. Try to read the file with platform default encoding again if the file cannot read with UTF-8 encoding
3. Clear encoding parameter in `compat_open` because `open` doesn't receive "encoding" parameter in binary mode

At the end of the day, if this is merged one can expect end users to do the following to get up and running;

aws configure
aws configure mfa

pull_requests.title: Use UTF-8 encoding when guessing a MIME type of text/html for S3 uploads.
pull_requests.body:
This PR addresses what I suspect is the most common cause of #1346, which is that `aws s3` guesses the MIME type of `.html` files as `text/html`, without any encoding specification.

This change simply alters any "guessed" `text/html` MIME type to be guessed as `text/html; charset=utf-8` instead. It's a bit of a stop-gap measure to address #1346, but given that the issue is now almost 2 years old, I thought this PR might be worth making in any case.

In terms of relevant statistics to justify this PR, [this somewhat dubious report](https://w3techs.com/technologies/details/en-utf8/all/all) suggests that:

> **UTF-8 is used by 88.5%** of all the websites whose character encoding we know.

My gut feeling also tells me that UTF-8 is a more sensible guess for encoding in 2017, rather than omitting the encoding from the `text/html` MIME type which, in the HTTP specification, means `ISO-8859-1`.

pull_requests.title: Some fixes to PEP8 code style
s3.sync: Do not stat files that don't match filters
pull_requests.body:
This probably helps on issue #1138.

I have a HUGE `~/src` directory that contains projects that I clone from various version control systems. Which makes me want to avoid backing them up on my personal S3 bucket to save some coins. For that, I used the `--exclude="src/*"` parameter (I also make sure the `aws` command is called from my `$HOME` directory, since I learned that the filters start matching from the current directory -- more details can be found in the #1588 issue). Although it worked, it still scanned and stat'ed the entire directory.

This patch changes the `FileGenerator` class to
1. take the filters from the command line as a parameter in its constructor
2. Use the `file_filter` parameter to match the path received by `.should_ignore_file` and figure out if the path received by the method is allowed by the filters.

This patch can be considered a work in progress because I only tested my specific need. It still needs proper tests. I didn't really write any because I wanted to ask if the strategy I chose is enough. If that's the case, I'd spend time writing the proper tests. Otherwise, I'd love to hear a better idea. I may be able to rework it if it's not too time consuming.

pull_requests.body: This fix has the nice benefit of constructing filters once, but the downside of being horribly specific.

pull_requests.title: Add --copy-acl option to s3-to-s3 transfers
pull_requests.body: This PR addresses issue #901 by adding a `--copy-acl` option to the `s3 sync`, `s3 cp`, and `s3 mv` commands.

pull_requests.title: Added option to compare on ETag/MD5
pull_requests.body:
We have a use case for s3 sync in which we update a staging bucket with production data.  However, the current comparator options will fail to update keys in the staging bucket when they have been updated more recently than the production keys but do not differ in size.

This change adds a --compare-on-etag option that uses the ETag of the key or the md5 of the local file to determine whether or not the source and destination differ.

It can be made to work but it's not easy.  Because there are embedded double-quotes within the option value, you must find a way to escape the string so the shell doesn't try to interpret the strings.  In most Linux-type shells, you can escale the entire string by enclosing it in single-quotes.  In Windows, however, it uses double-quotes as the escape character so you have to wrap the entire value in double-quotes and then escape individual embedded double-quotes with the backslash character, like this:

```
(testcli) C:\Users\Administrator\testcli>aws sqs set-queue-attributes
--queue-url https://us-west-2.queue.amazonaws.com/419278470775/foobar 
--attributes "{\"MaximumMessageSize\":\"2048\"}"
```

This is obviously tedious beyond words and we need to come up with something to help out here but until then, that is the workaround.  Or, put the JSON values in a file and include that via the `file:` prefix.

The help for `run-instances` shows this example for the `--block-device-mapping` option:

```
          Parameter Syntax

          [
            {
              "device_name": "string",
              "virtual_name": "string",
              "no_device": "string",
              "ebs": {
                {
                  "delete_on_termination": true|false,
                  "snapshot_id": "string",
                  "volume_size": integer,
                  "volume_type": "standard"|"io1",
                  "iops": integer
                }
            }
            ...
          ]
```

So, it is expecting a list of structures.  Your file contains just a structure.  Also, note the use of underscores rather than camelcase.  I think if you change your file to look like this:

```
[{"device_name":"/dev/sdf",
  "ebs":{
      "volume_size":1000,
      "delete_on_termination":true,
      "volume_type":"io1",
     "iops":1000}}]
```

It should work

Hmm, `rds.amazonaws.com` is a CNAME record pointing to `rds.us-east-1.amazonaws.com`. This causes problems with SSL certificate validation on all versions of Python < 2.7.3.

If you are using a version of Python >= 2.7.3, try doing this:

```
aws rds <subcommand> --endpoint-url https://rds.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/ ...
```

I also thought it would be useful to document the basic steps in generating documentation, as the code exists now.
1. Create a document object to contain the generated documentation.  At the moment, the only document type is ReSTDocument but there could be others.  The idea is for these documents to provide all of the high-level abstractions (e.g. new_paragraph(), start_ul(), etc.) so that the handler code can just use these high-level abstractions to generate the necessary documentation and not be dependent on any particular format.
2. Register the event handlers you want to use.  For the main document types (e.g. Provider, Service, Operation) we have event handler classes that contain all of the necessary event handlers for that document type.  So, we can just create an instance of one of those classes and call it's initialize() method to get the handlers registered.  If someone wanted to create a different type of document, or a variation of one of the existing documents they would need to implement and register their own handlers.
3. Cause the appropriate events to be generated for the type of document you want.  Again, for the standard document types we have built-in functions in `clidocevents.py` to generate the right events in the right order.  If someone needed a different type of document, something other than the current Provider, Service, Operation docs, they would need to implement something to fire the right events in the right order.  They may also have to define some new events.

We use the `HelpCommand` and it's subclasses to pass state from the CLI to the event handlers.  Anything you need to have when generating the documentation should be added as attributes to the `HelpCommand` object.  The most important thing in the `HelpCommand` is the document container object we created in step 1.

It shouldn't.  It's supposed to just be the hexdigest of the MD5 checksum of the public key with a bit of manipulation of the hexdigest characters.  See:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6682815/deriving-an-ssh-fingerprint-from-a-public-key-in-python

But at the moment, I'm having trouble getting this value to match that returned by an `aws ec2 describe-key-pairs` request so I'm looking into this a bit more.

from the private key file.  That's not how openssl computes it.  Are they
just extracting the public key from the pem file and then generating the
fingerprint from that?  It's not really very well specified and I can't
seem to get any variation of the fingerprint that I'm generating locally to
match what EC2 is sending me.
