> There's two problems here, one is that the cli is missing an abspath (otherwise we'll assume the current drive is where we should be looking). The other is that the data path in botocore uses : as the separator for environment variables, which is standard in the posix world, but on windows env vars use ; to separate variables because a path can have a : character in it, and splitting on : would not give us what we want:

> > > > 'C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files\Amazon\cfn-bootstrap\'
> > > > os.environ['PATH'].split(':')
> > > > ['C', '\Windows\system32;C', '\Windows;C', '\Windows\System32\Wbem;C', '\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C', '\Program Files\Amazon\cfn-bootstrap\']
> > > > Working on a fix for this now. I'll add the appropriate abspath call in the cli and I'll add a windows specific separator char for these path env vars.

Slight update to ensure pygments has json support before using it. Older versions of pygments didn't have json support until https://github.com/orb/pygments-json was merged.
Updated PR to catch all errors when trying to use the pygments JSON lexer, as throws its own exceptions rather than ImportError if it can't find a specific lexer.
Updated PR to fix compatibility with Python 3 - Travis build now passes. Also rebased on top of latest commit to develop branch.

It would be easy to make pygments a dependency for aws-cli. But it's also a judgement call by the maintainers, it makes the install a bit heavier and isn't a requirement.  @garnaat : Do you think this PR is useful, and what are your thoughts on a pygments dependency?

No, pip doesn't provide user prompted optional dependencies. Prompting the user would only confuse them anyway - the library should make a reasonable choice for devs - whether to provide it or not. The docs can state they can get colored output merely by doing a `pip install pygments`

I rebased the PR to the head of the develop branch, and changed it so that colorized output is only produced when writing to a stream that .isatty(). Thanks for the suggestion, that should have been the correct behavior the whole time.

Pygments support is indeed optional. If you don't have pygments installed with this PR, it will fall back to straight uncolorized output.

I made the zsh completion work for zsh using the bash compatibility mode of zsh. It's [here](https://github.com/a8/aws-cli/commit/c0ac1993b2e153866110af72e82e1aac3bb4dfc6). I tested the Mac Mountain Lion shipped zsh, upstream zsh 5.0.2 and zsh 4.3.17 Ubuntu 12.04. In order to work around the issue described above I copied the just applied [zsh fix](http://zsh.cvs.sourceforge.net/viewvc/zsh/zsh/Completion/bashcompinit?r1=1.5&r2=1.6) or [on the github clone](https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh/commit/edab1d3dbe61da7efe5f1ac0e40444b2ec9b9570).

It works. To make use of the greatness of zsh I will try to write a proper zsh compdef function in the next weeks. First I have to learn a little more about zsh ;-)


I haven't looked to see if short_name is used anywhere else, but this fixed my install.

I installed the tools using easy_install which pulls botocore from http://pypi.python.org/packages/source/b/botocore/botocore-0.4.2.tar.gz, and this tarball has the same issue.

Patching either botocore-0.4.2-py2.6.egg/botocore/data/aws/_services.json as above, or patching botocore-0.4.2-py2.6.egg/botocore/data/aws/cloudwatch.json fixes the problem.

Perhaps we need a "service_name" attribute in the JSON config?

or <<"endpoint_name": "monitoring">> like EMR or ELB seems better 
than my patch, which assign every endpoint URL for each.

I'll try to change and make pull req again to botocore project.

for CloudWatch endpoints assignment in _services.json, 
"endpoint_name": "monitoring" does not work, and "short_name": "monitoring" does work.

It is differ from the setting for Elastic Load Balancing service,
that is, "endpoint_name": "elasticloadbalancing" does work as expected.

 I think the ideal way to modify the endpoint URL which differs from the service name is to use "endpoint_name".

Great question.  Having a unified CLI across all AWS services is a high priority for us and is much requested by our customers.  Once we reach full service support and match feature parity with the existing CLI tools, then we’ll address ways to help those using the existing CLIs take advantage of the new unified AWS CLI.  We’ll tailor the migration approach for each service and its set of customers individually.  So the answer is - Yes, in the long term we’d like to align all customers onto our unified AWS CLI, but the migration path and timing for each service is yet to be determined.  If you’re already moving your existing CLI scripts to the AWS CLI, then we’d love to hear what parts of that process could be made easier.

Okay, I figured it out ... I hope this issue (and comment) helps others.

The correct syntax is:

```
[{"parameter_key":"ExampleParameter","parameter_value":"1234"}]
```

If you need to supply multiple parameters, the syntax is:

```
[ {"parameter_key":"Param1","parameter_value":"1234"},{"parameter_key":"Param2","parameter_value":"1234"} ]
```

issue_comments.body:
Tried the above but still failing.   I copied the exact line (just to test it), but it is not passing syntax checking:

ubuntu$ aws ec2 describe-instances --filters '[{"name":"instance-state-name","values":["pending"]}]'

Structure option value must be JSON or path to file.
That worked...thanks.
Definitely non-obvious. Thanks.

Try:

```
 aws ec2 describe-instances --filters '{"name":"instance-state-name","values":["pending"]}'
```

"(list)" in "aw2 ec2 describe-instances help" is "'string' 'string' '...'" not JSON's list format.
So you can more than one filter definition as following:

```
aws ec2 describe-instances --filters '{"name":"instance-state-name","values":["pending"]}' '{"name":"tag:Name","values": ["web*","db*"]}'
```

thanks for listening.  Output options are key to making this whole project useful.

I am getting similar issue with s3 create-bucket where I try to pass a "--create-bucket-configuration" which is json not xml. I have tried escaping the { and " with not luck.

Example:

aws --region us-west-2 s3 create-bucket --bucket blah.blah  --create-bucket-configuration '{"location_constraint":"us-west-2"}'

Yep! I just upgraded awscli to 0.10.0 (pip install --upgrade awscli).  These are now working:

Create bucket in non-east location:

```
aws --region us-west-2 s3 create-bucket --bucket x.y.z --create-bucket-configuration '{"location_constraint":"us-west-2"}' 
```

Configure static S3 website:

```
aws-cli$ aws s3 put-bucket-website --bucket x.y.z --website-configuration '{"index_document":{"suffix":"index.html"}}'
```

Thanks! 

Xueshan

I just saw the other issue that had been opened and is now closed describing the issue with [profile xxxx] not working in the config file.  I've tried it with the profiles defined as [profile testing] and [profile test1] with the same results as above.

I've redone the .aws file with [profile foo] and it is now finding the credentials. I found a typo on the test1 profile where I'd left the _id off of aws_access_key_id. The testing profile with the temporary keys is still not working. The credentials are found, but the AWS is responding with ``` 2013-05-29 18:47:09,011 - botocore.response - DEBUG - Response Body: Sender InvalidClientTokenId The security token included in the request is invalid. b2544600-c8b1-11e2-8ed4-9b2cda5997b1 ``` This is for temporary credentials just issued...

Ok, I've solved the temporary credentials issue.  The proper variable name in the config file is "aws_security_token", not "token"  the table in README.rst describing the config variables is not clear on this point.
LGTM. :shipit:

review_comments.body: Some explanation here about what needs refactoring might be nice.
Why is this hard-coded & where does the number come from? Feels like something that should maybe be an instance variable for (optional) tweaking.

I presume this is the error code to be emitted? I'd make it a class/instance-level variable. Also, since you're not calling `sys.exit(...)` here, a comment about how this should eventually make it back to the shell would be nice.
This could just be `return ...`, allowing the next line to be removed.
Some kwargs here might be nice, since there's a lot going on.

Should this not be calling `super(ServiceHelpCommand, self).__init__(...)` here? I don't know what `CLICommand` does, but if it needs to do any setup in the future, this won't run it, leading to potential bugs.
What if the name is a single dashed arg? (i.e. `-n`). Is that possible?
Should this fail with a `KeyError` if the type isn't present? Or would a different exception (or perhaps a fallback) be preferable?
A comment explaining what's going on here would be nice. I think I get it, but only because I have additional context.
Why are you accessing `.__dict__...` here? Seems kinda poor-form.
"get_paramter()" -> "get_parameter()"
Feel like maybe this ought to be in the `formatter` itself, since this method isn't doing an I/O itself?
This comment ought to be copied to the above method if it still applies.
I hate to be that guy, but I feel like maybe some assumptions in other places could be caught by using a non-classic region here.
Do we really want to assert there are double-spaces around "AWS"?

I understand it's a smoke test, but this feels like it's not really checking the shorthand params. The command could be doing something completely wrong but as long as it's not exiting with an error code, this will pass.
Does this `return` cause the test method to pass without running the assertions inside?
If other people want to run this test case, won't this fall down for them?
Could this ever be any other collection, like a `tuple`?
It doesn't appear like this import is used anywhere (that I can find).
A comment here about why this is a `pass` would be nice. It's not immediately obvious.
This block is kinda weird. Why not just `if self.operation == 'delete': yield src_path, size, last_update` & drop the `else` case?

Why all the explicit calls to flush? Those aren't typically needed, unless you either need immediate feedback on the console (unlikely) or to prevent too much output from getting buffered (& consuming RAM).

Got it. That's a good reason, but if it's going to be all over the code, I'd pull it out into a `safe_print` function that combines `uni_print` & the flush, so that it doesn't get forgotten anywhere. Doesn't need to block the ship, but it'd be nice to have IMO.
I'd make this a link to the Pip docs, on the odd chance someone doesn't have it already.
Perhaps make this a docstring instead? That way it gets to the HTML docs & is more discoverable than having to look at the source?

Is there anything before the JSON in the output? What I'm wondering is if this can be converted into `self.assertTrue(p.stdout.startswith('{', p.stdout)` to ensure it's actually starting the right way & not just the right character being present elsewhere in the output.
A comment here would really help. I don't understand why you'd be inserting this into the parameters?
I mean, I'm assuming it's a reasonable default (like unexpected data). But it'd be nice if it was clear.
The way this lines up at right is pretty amazing. Nothing to change, just sayin'. :D
Typically in reST, you match the line lengths with the header text. It won't be a warning while building (only if the line is too short), but it's generally good style.
As someone on the relative outside, it'd be nice to have a docstring here describing what this was for. The other properties are relatively obvious, but this one is a mystery.
Sneaky.
Does `requests` need to be in this list or no (because no C exts)?
Context? Connects?
Is this right?
Same thing here? Aren't these needed or is that covered by the `html_theme_options` above?
Is there anything around this call that can be asserted? There's no pre-condition asserting the S3 key isn't already there AFAICT (unsure if `self.create_bucket()` will silently pass or not).
Is this TODO staying?

Not a reflection of this test, but is there another similar test asserting about other content-types (since IIRC the CLI is inferring on that)? A `.json` file would be enough for me, just to make sure that portion of the code is working.
I'm cool with it being there if it's serving a purpose, just wasn't sure if it was accidental or not.
Seems odd to be doing a flush here, when there isn't any other STDOUT things directly happening in this method.
One more weird flush.
LOL, I'm a moron. "Looking to improve your multipart uploads? Try this one weird flush!"
Is it worth pulling out the chuck size so it can be modified/overridden/shared? Or not so much?

I wouldn't use `First,` here, because you aren't listing any other argument types by name.

issue_comments.body:
Here is an example starting a t1.micro with a root device of 20 Gb instead of 8 using command line and not file.  Region is us-east.

~$ aws ec2 run-instances --image-id ami-5675ee3f --min-count 1 --max-count 1 --instance-type t1.micro --block-device-mapping '{"device_name":"/dev/sda1", "ebs":{"volume_size":20}}'

aws --version
aws-cli/0.5.1 Python/2.7.3 Linux/3.2.0-31-virtual

Silly Q...but how do I find current version number in github ?

How to do multiple devices on command line or in file ? I cannot get the list (using JSON array) to work for one device or multiple.  While I have the command working for one device (see comment above) cannot do it for multiple devices.  Region is US East. Thanks.

Single element in array:
~$ aws ec2 run-instances --image-id ami-5675ee3f --min-count 1 --max-count 1 --key-name histdata --instance-type t1.micro --block-device-mapping '{[{"device_name":"/dev/sda1", "ebs":{"volume_size":20}}]}'  
Expecting property name: line 1 column 1 (char 1)

Multiple elements in array:
~$ aws ec2 run-instances --image-id ami-5675ee3f --min-count 1 --max-count 1 --key-name histdata --instance-type t1.micro --block-device-mapping ' { [{"device_name":"/dev/sda1", "ebs":{"volume_size":20} }, {"device_name":"/dev/xvdf", "ebs":{"volume_size":10} } ] } '
Structure option value must be JSON or path to file.

Same result with outer braces removed:

~$ aws ec2 run-instances --image-id ami-5675ee3f --min-count 1 --max-count 1 --key-name histdata --instance-type t1.micro --block-device-mapping '  [{"device_name":"/dev/sda1", "ebs":{"volume_size":20} }, {"device_name":"/dev/xvdf", "ebs":{"volume_size":10} } ]  '
Structure option value must be JSON or path to file.

review_comments.body: I should be able to refactor the service creation code into a public method.
Does it make sense to put a short `time.sleep` here? How long does this test typically take to run? Up to 30 seconds seems like a long time to busy loop.
Is line 71 not the same as 107? I'm not sure what you mean here.
This looks like something is missing...
Any reason for `not` and `==` here instead of `!=`?
Was this left in on purpose?

This is to handle custom arguments and parameters where they may not have a name attribute or may not even be a param object. Due to the flexibility of the custom argument system this is required, but I can change it to be something like `'anonymous'` instead. Would you prefer that or just omitting the final `.` when the name is not known? I'm not sure how much value there is in listening for only anonymous params.

Unfortunately the existing `load-cli-arg` event sets a botocore operation argument as one of its parameters sent to handlers. I can't remove it in a backwards compatible way, so it has to stay. I'm open to suggestions for workarounds though.
Done
In this case is the correct behavior to create a subclass which sets up `_run_main` and then instantiate that instead of `BasicCommand`?

The third argument (`self`) winds up using `self.name`, which is the operation name. The second argument (`custom` above) is the service name, and for custom arguments we cannot know the service name (or there may be no service name), so I just used `custom` instead. I'm open to suggestions for a better way to do this.

We could add an optional service name parameter in the constructor to be passed in alongside the session, but no existing custom commands will use it unless we update them.
Done
I'll remove it in favor of just the operation name. The event handler (currently only one is defined in the codebase) will get a service name and operation name, but no service or operation objects.

I've used a subclass instead. I can't just use `__call__` directly because it has logic I want tested in it, and it then calls `_run_main` which by default raises and exception. The subclass is working nicely and prevents the initial problem.

Unfortunately we have code that doesn't always work when I make it required. For some reason the BasicCommand class allows unknown arguments to be passed for example. We should look at changing that in a future commit IMO.

Presumably putting this into a shared compat file means others might want to use it. Can we add some documentation (even just one sentence as a description) about what this does? It's a public function and not immediately obvious unless I track down where it is used below.
Since `'r'` is the default we can omit it here.
Good point - I'll update it.
